utterances.sentences: You are No. 1. And it is now time for "One More Thing." Greg, you're up first.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, some people just mail in shows, you know, where they chop it all up, do greatest hits. Jesse. "The Greg Gutfeld Show" tomorrow night is brand-new. It's fresh. It's got Morgan Ortagus, Jim Florentine, Kat Timpf, Tyrus. Saturday December 29, 10 p.m. You're going to love every piece of that show. And more.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: I already do, and you know why? Because it is the appetizer for New Year's Eve. We talked a little bit about it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That is true.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: So excited to be broadcasting live from Times Square right here in glorious New York City with my cohost, Pete Hegseth, this year. And of course, kicking off the main event in the 8 p.m. hour, Carley Shimkus and Griff Jenkins. Jedediah will be there. Lawrence Jones will be in New Orleans. We're also going to have Tomi Lahren, Tyrus, as well.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Kathy Griffin?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Kathy Griffin will not be there. But we will perhaps see --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She's free!

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: -- a Nancy Pelosi experience. She -- she may be making an appearance on the show. I'm not saying what she's doing but --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: -- can't wait for it. All right. Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: All right. I want to introduce you to Nubby, who's the sweetest 7- year-old chihuahua. He was born with just his back legs. He was abandoned and was rescued. And now he brings joy as a therapy dog to patients at Cardon Children's Medical Center. He walks around. He uses his little wheelchair for his back legs, and he goes from room to room to people who are also struggling, who are kids who are in casts who are suffering, to kind of say, "Hey, look, I overcame my struggle. You can, too." They absolutely love him. And people just underestimate oftentimes how much joy these animals can bring to people who are in hospitals or struggling with conditions.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a cruel nickname.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Nubby.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: What is, Nubby?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: It's kind of cute.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: He seems happy.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: He looks very happy. Very, very happy. Very well taken care of. And very inspirational. I love him. And he's beautiful.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: He's got buns of steel, that dog.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: He does. He really does.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Very impressive.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Quite a fitness pro.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Very sweet. All right. Marie.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Staying on the dog theme. Even though I'm a cat person, we're staying on the dog theme. "The Daily Briefing's" dog, Spike, who if you follow social media, if you follow Dana or "Daily Briefing" online, you know Spike. He and some of his canine companions got a sneak peek at the Times Square, New Year's Eve ball. Take a look at these photos. I can only imagine how fun this was for these dogs. They had the lights and they had these huge - - I don't know. Huge things out there in Times Square. If you look at that, I mean, that's Spike and his buddies got to go on a field trip, which I love. BILA: Ohh.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: It's a dog's life.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: It's a dog's -- I mean, they're getting ready for New Year's Eve. I don't think they'll be there with you, Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do you know these dogs don't know it's New Year's Eve. I just want everybody to know that. That dogs do not know.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: You don't know that, Gregory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, they don't. They don't know. They do not know it's New Year's Eve. It's just another loud evening of obnoxious giant fleshy beasts that are taller than them that make lots of noise and light off stupid things. And they just want the sound to go away. No animal likes New Year's Eve. They don't like Fourth of July. They hate it. They crawl under the bed, as do I.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: You know what they do like, though?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Treats.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They do like treats. But who doesn't like a good treat?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Maybe they get special treats on New Year's.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: You just ruined that moment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I tried to ruin it, Marie.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: All right. Successful. Lawrence, you do not have an easy task this evening with "One More Thing." I give it to you, buddy.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Our friend Bre Payton, many of you know her as a writer for The Federalist, a frequent guest on television news, including Fox News, sadly died after a sudden illness, according to her employer. Bre was born June 8, 1992, and tragically passed today at the age of 26. She was kind. She was smart, and she was truly the life of the party. The California native is survived by her parents and her four siblings.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think we all know, we all knew her on various shows. She was on your show. She was on my show, and we've all worked with her.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's a terrible shock. It's just -- it's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: And she -- you know, an absolutely beautiful soul. I loved having her on. And it's -- it's tough for her family and The Federalist family, as well.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: And us at Fox News. Bre, we're going to miss you. Bre, my story for Bre is I spent her birthday with her this year, after Kennedy's show, and she was so kind. And she wanted to -- everybody loved her, because she was a genuine soul. And she really cared about all you guys out there. Bre, we're going to miss you.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Rest in peace.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Rest in peace.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Eternal be her memory. "Special Report" is up next. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 ASC Services II Media, LLC. All materials herein are protected by United States copyright law and may not be reproduced, distributed, transmitted, displayed, published or broadcast without the prior written permission of ASC Services II Media, LLC. You may not alter or remove any trademark, copyright or other notice from copies of the content.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I am Kennedy along with Jedediah Bila, Mari Harf, Lawrence Jones and Greg Gutfeld. It is 5 o'clock in New York City. And this is The Five. This is a Fox News alert. The illegal immigrant wanted for killing a police officer in California arrested after a massive 48-hour manhunt. The sheriff in charge of the investigation blaming sanctuary laws saying the suspect had two previous DUI arrests. And if he had been reported Officer Ron Singh would still be alive. Authorities also saying the suspect had known gang affiliations and was trying to flee to Mexico. The slain officer was shot and killed during a traffic stop on Wednesday morning. Two others have also been arrested for helping the suspected murderer evade capture. Police announcing the arrest at an emotional press conference with the officer's family. Watch.

utterances.speaker: ADAM CHRISTIANSON, STANILAUS COUNTY SHERIFF
utterances.utterance: I am pleased and very proud of the fact that the suspect is in custody. He has been apprehended in Bakersfield. He was safely taken into custody earlier today by teams from the Kern County Sheriff's Office and other law enforcement agencies, who have helped us relentlessly pursue this suspect in pursuit of justice. Gustavo Perez Arriaga, 33 years old, again was arrested earlier today during the execution of a search warrant. He was found at a residence in Bakersfield Kern County area. And we will get into the specifics of that. First, I want to introduce Officer Ron Singh's brother, Reggie. He would like to share a few words with all of you.

utterances.speaker: REGGIE SINGH, BROTHER OF RON SINGH
utterances.utterance: Please bear with me. This is not easy for me. Ronil Singh was my brother. Yes, he is not coming back. But there is a lot of people out there that misses him. And a lot of law enforcement people that I don't know who worked days and nights to make this happen, I would like to thank you from the bottom of my heart. You made this happen. I wish I could thank all of the law enforcement agencies, Homeland Security in San Francisco, everyone, Bakersfield team. I was waiting for this to happen. I would like to thank you working day and night to make this happen. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Absolutely devastating. So, Greg, what does this do to our conversation right now about immigration and the border wall?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, first of all, it's obviously tragic, but it's also infuriating. It's infuriating because it was wholly preventable, if you stick to the facts. He's an illegal who entered the country illegally, obviously illegal, he was a part of a notorious street gang. He had a couple of arrests and he murdered a police officer on Christmas Day. Now, you could possibly notion that illegal immigrants are less violent than the legal population or the people born here. That's fine. But, you know, more Americans die from heart decease than from cancer. That doesn't mean you don't fight cancer. OK. So, that argument goes away. The fact is that if you have prevented his illegal immigration, you would have a police officer, a good man who is still alive. Second part now leads to the media will accuse people like us of using a tragedy in order to impact political discourse. Where did we learn that from, right? After a natural disaster is linked to climate change, after every mass shooting is linked to lack of gun control. When the child of an illegal immigrant attempts to cross the country and ends up the hospital, that's because we're a cold heartless country, who didn't treat these people correctly. So we've learned this. It makes me think that perhaps we should be using these tragedies. What else can we do? We see that this is wholly preventable. And what's really infuriating, it happened while we were having this discussion. We have been having this rolling discussion for two years about this. And it happened. If only someone had listened to it before, he would be alive. It's something that just people go you are using this. No, this is actually evidence that something has to be done.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Marie.

utterances.speaker: MARIE HARF, HOST
utterances.utterance: I think what we have seen this week with this case, with one of the cases Greg mentioned, one of the children who had died in custody, Kate Steinle in San Francisco, just the countless stories of people who go to great physical dangers to come to this country, is that the lack of an immigration policy that works in this country is incredibly tragic and heart breaking. It has tragic consequence that ripple in so many different ways.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: But let me ask you one specific question. What do you say to the people who argue that sanctuary cities often times protect people just like this? Not hard-working immigrants who are doing whatever they can to get a foothold in this country, and make lives better for themselves and for their families. But for people like this, who have prior arrests, who shouldn't have been in the country, especially after putting other people's lives at risk with DUI arrests, and you know, they essentially are shielded. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Here is what I would say. We need to take a look at everything and try to figure out what the solutions would be. Is a border wall actually something that would be a solution? There are Republicans like Will Hurd from Texas, a congressman, who actually said it would not be a good solution. There are smart people who not believe this is the right solution. Is cracking down on sanctuary cities something that would have an evidence- based, demonstrable impact? I don't know the answer. I'm not an expert. But what is so frustrating about this shutdown is we are obsessed with this one thing. The wall. Can we get DACA for the wall, which I actually think or some wall funding which I think would be a good tradeoff. But the broader picture here, is the wall the right thing, what role do sanctuary cities play, what should we do with DACA, what about visa overstays which is a huge problem? These big issues are not being tackled right now.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE JONES, HOST
utterances.utterance: But, Marie...

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And that is what's really tragic in all of this. We get bogged down in the day-to-day, both sides go to equal extreme opposites and nobody is willing to come to the middle.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And I think part of the reason why is because I believe a lot of Democrats are being disingenuous when it comes to the wall. We have reached the point of two things. We know that Mexico is not going to pay for the wall and that we're not going to have a wall over the entire border. That's not going to happen. Both sides know that's not going to happen.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: We know that the president is going to get some type of border security.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: And we're going to talk about border security in just a little bit. But, you know, let's talk about this officer, because this is tragic.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: This happened at Christmas' time. And every law enforcement family in the country feels that pain because that's your biggest fear.

utterances.speaker: JEDEDIAH BILA, HOST
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: The person you love who wears a uniform to keep other people safe is not going to come home. His family is devastated, his department are devastated. Are we having the right kind of conversation about it?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I think that's a great point, too, when you're looking he has a five- month-old and just watching the video of the people who worked with him, the officers. I think a lot of times people forget that these law enforcement officials, they really are a family. And they go out every single day and risk their lives for us. And when you see their reaction, there is a component of this that is preventable. There was no way you could watch this and somehow step back and defend sanctuary cities. I mean, that is a part of the conversation that should not be happening. There are good people on both sides of the debate about immigration, you want to talk about comprehensive reform, even when we talk about the wall. You made good points. Some people feel maybe the wall is in the best route or maybe the wall isn't the only route. It has to be coupled with other things. But you're going to watch this and somehow defend a sanctuary city that defies federal law and mayors like the mayor of Oakland who comes out and lambastes ICE and says to its residents, you know, I will give you a warning to protect you from ICE. Border patrol agents have been vilified, ICE has been vilified. And there are people in this country who are a known risk, who have a known record, and they are being allowed to exist here. And you have to prevent these people from being able to get here and not being held accountable for what they are doing.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I think, you know, part of what Marie is saying is that you do need a better system.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: And the government has failed us utterly in terms of immigration because people like that should not be in the country. People like that who want to hurt people and so easily takes someone's life, because this guys knows that if he was arrested, he would have be deported. It would have been his third DUI arrest. And he has got a gang-affiliated tattoo on his arm.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Here's the thing. Crimes like this can happen if you take a political or symbolic stance at the risk of the citizens. It's like a sanctuary city is essentially a risk that you place on citizens for a symbolic gesture. It's a symbolic virtue signal. Hey, we care. We're not like Trump, we're not like the rest of everybody else. We care for our cities. Never mind that that actually elevates risk. So the whole thing is a travesty, because it's designed to actually make certain people feel better, while you pay the price.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: When the media covers this though, you had to sieve through. When I looked at the headlines of this story, you have to sieve through paragraph -- one article in paragraph 7, you had to get to before they said that this person was here illegally. And then you have the parallel of Trump being vilified every day for talking about a wall, for prioritizing border security, for talking about drug trafficking and gang violence.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Do we know that he came in through an illegal port of entry?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I think the details are still emerging here. All of this is tragic, right. A police officer being killed by a citizen is also tragic. We have to look at how things are preventable and how we fix this system. And I think that both sides are good at vilifying the other. You know, these children that are dying in DHS custody, that has to stop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But that was in a hospital, wasn't it? The second one was in a hospital. I think technically it is custody, but that's also people trying to save their lives.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: In order to stop that, you secure the border. That's how you stop it. Because you stop incentivizing people to go through conditions to get here.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. Under our laws, showing up and applying for asylum is still legal.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: If we want to make that illegal, we can change the laws. My point is the immigration system in our country needs fixing.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: It does.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: So why isn't Nancy Pelosi saying the first thing we are going to do is fix immigration? The first thing they are going to do is to shove the shutdown in the president's face to show they are resisting. Resisting is not fixing immigration. And figuring out how to get good people in the country and the right number of people who can fill the jobs there are critically important.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: ICE agents are not getting paid today though because of the shutdown.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But, you know, we have spent the last three weeks. I was at the Times Man of the Year. Journalists are those that are in danger under Trump's America. We have seen a 12-percent increase in police killed in the line of duty from 2018 to 2017, it was like 144 have been killed. That's where the risk is.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When it comes to every one of these stories, no matter how political it is, it's the guy who gets there first that gets shot.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: All right. Well, we're going to get somewhere first. And that's the government shutdown. It's not stopping Nancy Pelosi from vacationing in Hawaii.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Oh, so hot. I hope she is in a bikini right now. We've got all of that next. Stay here.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: President Trump threatening to seal the southern borders after talks to reopen the government stalled. We're also learning that President Trump is skipping his annual New Year's Eve party in Mar-A-Lago due to the shutdown. Fox News confirming now that Nancy Pelosi, soon to become Speaker of the House, is not in D.C. She is on vacation. White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders going after the Democratic leader earlier.

utterances.speaker: SARAH SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: Right now what we have seen from her is that she is unwilling to do actually anything until she gets her speakership. She is more willing to protect that than to protect our borders and protect American lives. And we'll see that change in the next couple of days.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And Republicans calling Senator Chuck Schumer a hypocrite for comments he made about border security in 2009.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: Illegal immigration is wrong, plain and simple. Until the American people are convinced that we will stop future flows of illegal immigration, we will make no progress on dealing with the millions of illegal immigrants, who are here now and on rationalizing our system of legal immigration. We must do as much as we can to gain control of our borders as soon as possible.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: So, Lawrence, I have been thinking for a couple of days. We've talked about this a little bit yesterday. Is there a possible deal to be made here that the president gets let's say $2 million for the wall?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Two million?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Two billion, I'm sorry. It wasn't a great deal. It's Friday, guys. Two billion in exchange for something like DACA, right? Because it's clear that once the Democrats take over on January 3rd, they can pass a clean funding bill with no money for the wall, which could pass the Senate. Is that a deal that could that possibly work do you think?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think a deal is possible because they don't agree with the symbolic measure, right. They don't believe -- the whole theory of the wall, the campaign trail, he going down the escalators, all of that image to their voters, they just can't vote for anything like that. And so, they will never give him the wall because of the symbolic measure. But I think this highlights something. Looking at Chuck Schumer, what changed with him, what changed with Barack Obama?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: It's prescription?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Right. Something had to change. And that's why I started the last segment by saying I feel like the entire debate is disingenuous because they know. And I know they know because they said it in the past. You just cannot have an open border.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Right. Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It's interesting because I like that Chuck Schumer is being confronted with his own words here. As we make resolutions for the coming year, you have to look back on the resolutions you made last year. Did you fail yourself? Go back and look at last year's list and the year before. And I think that's what some of the Democrats have to do. Because they talk a big game, but for a lot of their voters, this is a nimby issue, not in my backyard. And they want to see something done on immigration. And you know, he acts so high and mighty now and so self-righteous, and he thinks he is so much better than the president in terms how he argues about immigration. And I may actually agree with Chuck Schumer on certain points. But when he said just a few years ago, people who went to the United States without our permission are illegal aliens. And illegal aliens should not be treated the same as people who entered the United States legally. That is an opposition to statements that he made.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Well, he probably still believes a version of that. And, Jedediah, one thing I think Democrats push back on -- I know you think it's just a symbolism of the wall, but to a lot of Democrats, we feel like the president is just saying the wall will fix it. If the wall end-all and be- all -- by the way, Mexico isn't going to pay for it. Now, taxpayers have to. It doesn't seem like the president is talking about a comprehensive fix.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Like a broader plan.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Yeah, exactly.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: That's true. That's a fair point. I think it would do him justice to actually broaden out from the wall and talk about the other issues as well. But you talked about what changed. One of the things that changed was Trump. Trump made this issue a prominent issue.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Republicans often times don't put this as a lead issue. This was a guy who was out on the campaign trail talking about immigration first, talking about this wall, talking about how Mexico will pay for the wall, which I thought was a mistake at that time, because I didn't see that happening. But he put it front and center. And by virtue of him doing that, everybody that loathed him now had to hate that policy. I mean, Chuck Schumer sounds like Donald Trump in that clip that we heard. He is echoing the very same talking point. But now, because this is Trump's issue and the wall has become a priority for Trump, when they oppose Trump, they have to oppose that measure, even if it is counterintuitive to what they've been saying for a very long time. So, I wonder how much of this is opposition to Trump or opposition to the actual policy?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: The president has talked about immigration in terms of filling some of the labor shortages here. And he has talked about needing workers. You are never going to hear most of the press talk about or cover the kind statements that he has made, which also can seem hypocritical. But the president also talks about the wall as a force field.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It's not necessarily a force field. It's not going to stop every type of illegal immigration and it's not going to stop drugs from coming in, because drugs come in through San Isidro, through the main ports of entry.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: That is actually not the best way to combat the drug problem in this country. There are other ways.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is why the argument doesn't go anywhere because there is this weird fallacy, that if somebody says the wall won't prevent X that negates the premise of the wall. Actually, yeah, the wall won't prevent overstayed visas, but a fence won't prevent a falling rock. Conflating the two, you actually negate the benefits of either, right.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So you can actually say, if you want something, here's what you do, you put up a fence. And here's what you do for the overstayed visa. The problem here -- that argument, it's gone, right. You can use the fence for this. You can use this for that. You don't need to do that anymore. We should move on. But we can't when it's personal, right. So this is now personal, because there is no impersonal reason to reject a compromise. And Donald Trump is willing to make a deal because he likes making deals. And let's face it, he's been moving toward the middle. Any time you're going to embrace DACA -- seriously, Marie, he is going to piss off a lot of people.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Not on this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He is willing to do anything for that wall. And it's idiotic that the Democrats -- he will budge because he knows you can get piece by piece.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's the question. Will he budge?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: For what?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But the point is it's not about him now. It's about Chancy, you know, Chuck and Nancy. Right now, this is like a divorce that stays together because of the kids. What you need right now is a mediator, right. You need a mediator to come in there. The mediator has to be an engineer who tells you exactly what is needed for the specific parts of the country. Because God knows these politicians don't know what it is. So they sit there and they fall back into their same arguments. The wall won't fix X. We will deal with that. Here's what the wall is good for. We do know they have walls around their compounds, they have walls around their swimming pools, they have walls around -- wherever she is staying in Hawaii has a wall.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Yes, you are right about DACA and conservatives, if DACA means amnesty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: If DACA equals amnesty, there is a very large...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If the Dems were pushing this agenda that Trump is actually offering, it would be hailed as a humanitarian effort by the media because it would help the job market, it would just create more jobs. And it would create a pathway to citizenship. The media would love this. But unfortunately, Trump is doing it. Any time Trump does something, the media has to hate it.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: We will see if he does veto some sort of bill once Congress comes back in a few days. We will keep watching it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Will we keep watching?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: We might now actually. In the meantime, some in the mainstream media continuing to go after Trump and his surprise trip to the Iraq. And now, he's taking more shots. See it next, stay tuned.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: The media is still talking about President Trump's surprise trip to visit the troops in Iraq. Here is what some of them are saying.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The president signing a campaign hat, a red hat, his Make America Great Again hat.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: The president seems to have confused in some way his troop visit with a campaign rally.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: He told me I am getting a 10-percent raise and I only get 2.6 percent raise, I'd be pretty pissed off, especially if I was in a war zone risking my life everyday.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The man does not believe in what America stands for.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: What did you make of that address that Donald Trump gave in front of U.S. troops in Iraq?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I thought it was obscene.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: When we turned on CNN and we saw the president politicizing a Christmas message, it's like we keep saying he's like the Grinch.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And of course, the media isn't stopping there. Some of them resent the press taking new shots at the president.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Look, he's still the president. And so, when he says something, it has a news value. It is up to us to decide what his news value is. He devalued the currency of his word. It's not just with the tweets, there is also devalue in the currency of his interviews.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: These are really turbulent times for Donald Trump. And I think he's more isolated that he's ever been.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: The president talks about the economy, this is one area that left to his own devices, he's pulling down the economy with.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: OK. Greg, I'm going to go to you first. It's a fair point to criticize the president for telling the troops that you know the percentage was higher.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's a big deal by the way.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That is a big deal. I said it's a fair point.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Let's be clear on that.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But the Washington Post said that he was shrewd in secrecy. He's the President of the United States, this happens with every administration, that they have to take precautions. Isn't the media is just gone all over the place?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, all of this stuff, this montage shows they don't like Trump. We get it, it's been going on for two years. We understand no matter what he does, you're going to hate. The thing you have to be alarmed about is the growing trend in which people find value in narking on others, right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's in social media, it's in schools, it's in media, it's on the street. It's people narking on other people, it's turning everybody into Gladys the next door neighbor from Bewitched. Jim Acosta CNN, they are now our nation's hall monitors, right. And it is a huge blind spot. It's like they can't see what they have become. So they're actually finking. They are finks. They're finking on troops because they brought a hat. I mean, how low are you to, like, make that a concern? It reminds me. There was another guy at CNN that, like, would write to Twitter about Donald Trump's tweets. "Did you see his tweet? Send." It was like these are grown men and women. Grown men and women who now crawl over decades of tweets, of celebrities, of comics, you name it to -- we are becoming a nation of narcs. So all this other stuff, I don't care. And Trump -- Trump made a mistake. Damn straight.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Keep saying it, over and over.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But it's the hat. No, I'm talking about the incident with the hat is a bigger issue. And somebody -- it's like when you have a friend with bad breath. CNN has bad breath. Somebody has to tell you, CNN, you've got bad breath. You've got to knock it off.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Or at least offer a mint.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Use a mint. Jim DeMint.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: The best since the line about "he devalued the currency of his worth."

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: He has.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I mean, what does that even -- it's so ridiculous, though. Like --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: It's not. I don't think that's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: If that's what you're picking on, if you're picking on that.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That one moment.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And then also the hats. And you're like, "Well, I don't know if that was right. What the military members did and him signing those hats." Listen, if that's what you're picking on, everything else is going really well. Because if the economy was a disaster --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a good point.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: If you're worried about terrorism, if you had real stuff to worry about, you would not be talking about this stuff. You're talking about this stuff, because everybody has more money in their pockets and have more money to spend. And they're not as worried about their --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They could spend it on hats.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It seems like they're making it about themselves. This was a moment for the troops. Did you see their faces? They were so excited. They were having it. They enjoyed the president. He always makes everything about him.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Here's the thing. I don't care about the hats. I don't care if he signed the hats. I think it's stupid to focus on the hats. I think we should focus on the fact that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What is it about hats you don't like, Marie? Are you anti- hatist?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: No, I'm not. The pay raise thing bothers me, because he said something to the troops that was not accurate about their own pay. And I don't like that. And he keeps saying it repeatedly.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Don't you think they know? I mean, they get their paychecks. They see what's in there.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: What Maggie Haberman was saying was that the president now says things so frequently that aren't true that what he says has lost some value. I think that's a bigger problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. But --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Greg, I think that's a bigger problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But see, your bigger problems are always undercut by the idiocy of the people on your side who chase hats. So once you go after the hat --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Jim Acosta is so outraged. Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Then we just shut down. I agree. I think it -- I'm trying to figure out how he got it inaccurate. So he said it was the largest increase in 10 years. It was actually the largest increase in nine years. Then he said 10 percent, but he probably meant 10 years. He -- it was false.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: No. He said -- he said, "I brought back pay cut -- pay raises, and you hadn't gotten them for a few years."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: He said, "You're getting 10 percent." That's not true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But the problem with your argument is, because you don't like the people making it --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: -- you dismiss all of legitimate criticism.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, no, no. What I'm saying is --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Let's get you in there, Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Because the thing that I found --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Because there is legitimate criticism.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: OK, the thing that I found most telling was what April Ryan said about the president bringing down the economy. It means that April Ryan is either a bad person, because she's hoping the economy does bad so the president does bad so he loses in 2020. That's a horrible thing to think. Because when the economy does bad, and people lose jobs, people die. That's not emotionalism. That is data. I mean, that is a sad fact of life. But when the economy tanks, there are vulnerable people who not live. So that is --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Wasn't that just her analysis, though Kennedy?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes, but he's pulling down the economy, so what is she looking at?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But that's --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: The Dow? Is that what she's looking at?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: His comments about the Fed.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Is she looking at the stock market?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: His comments about the Fed that lead to volatility in the stock market. That's a fact.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It's not his comments about the Fed.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Yes, it is.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It's the Fed raising rates.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And it's his trade war.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: And it's the idea that the Fed -- OK, I'm going to have my time. Because you had your time. You had two times. I'm going to go ahead and talk right now. Because the Fed is raising rates. The Fed operates in secret with no oversight. They manipulate our currency. They create booms and busts in the market, and it is is unacceptable. It is un-American. Central banking is horrible. The president has rightly pointed that out. I don't agree with a lot of the stuff he says on a number of issues, but this is somewhere he's absolutely right. And it's not his words about the Fed. It's the Fed themselves that are screwing with this. You'd have a better argument if you said the president and the way he's dealing with China and tariffs and trade.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: That's an issue that you have some ground to stand on. Here, no. Not at all. April Ryan either wants the economy to fail or she's not a very smart person and doesn't understand basic economics and is too lazy to look at other economic indicators.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, that got to be the last word.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, wait. I think that message was brought to us by Ron Paul.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: You're right. Buy gold!

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: The Internet goes into wild speculation about what caused the sky over New York City to turn to a bizarre blue last night. That and more. And "The Fastest Seven" is coming up next on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Welcome back, everyone. It is time for "The Fastest Seven." First up, a mysterious blue light hovering over New York City causes panic, confusion and wild conspiracy theories. Some people joking it could be aliens and end up like this. Turns out it was an explosion at a power plant. Fortunately, no one was injured by the blast. All right. So did anyone else see this and panic? Because I thought it was "War of the Worlds" as you might expect. My husband was on the couch, screamed.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Was it scary? Because I didn't see it. Was it scary?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: It was scary. Did anybody see this?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I didn't.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Nobody saw this?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I actually questioned whether it happened.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I was on FOX Business Network.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You guys -- you were working. Thank you for that, by the way.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I was sleeping.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: OK, so I saw it. Nice of you guys to choose this topic. Nobody saw it. But it really looked like if you know the end of the world movies. It looked like that. It looked like it was this bluish green, sudden explosion.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But what was it?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: So do you believe the -- do we believe the story?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Do you believe it? That's my thing. Do you believe it wasn't aliens?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't believe it. I don't believe it. You know what I believe? They're killing Smurfs. That's what it is. They're burning up Smurfs over there.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It's a smurfatorium.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a smurfatorium. You know what?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I hope we have no little (UNINTELLIGIBLE) today.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what's great. Is that everybody thought that it was -- everybody was joking about it. So when the real apocalypse comes, everybody's going to be on Twitter joking about the apocalypse, and they're going to die.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And that's going to be it. It's going to be "The Walking Dead."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: This is how they soften us up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: This is how we know the aliens are coming. Because they just ease in a few stories like this. And then there was a retired Air Force guy who says, no, this was all real and begged for declassification of documents. And the movies become more and more realistic, and then all of a sudden, it's "Mars Attacks." Ack!

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'm not buying this explosion stuff. That bluish? Normally, it's fire that comes up when it's an explosion.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: How many of these have you seen normally?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I'm just saying. Well --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: In the movies --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: On TV, you know.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I've seen the aurora borealis. It was like that.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: So it's smoke.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I think I might have had a small panic attack.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: yes. There are two types of people in this world. There's the people that panic when they see something like that and the people that don't. I --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's the people who drink.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Well, that's true.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I panic and then drink.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Can I do them together?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: All right. Well, up next, remember trying to get through homework as a kid? Well, one six-year-old found a new way to get some extra help. Check this out.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Alexa, what's five minus three?

utterances.speaker: ROBOTIC VOICE
utterances.utterance: Five minus three equals two.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Boy!

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: That's young boy's mother --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That sounds like my Mama!

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: -- busting him using Alexa to make things easier. This kid is pretty smart, as far as I can see.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: That's a baller, yes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I wouldn't have thought of that.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Do we trust Alexa to give the right answers?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: That's a good point.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: She speaks --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, the kid sound like my Mama, because she always used to tell me, "You're too smart for your own good, Lawrence." And so I like this. You know, these kids are getting way too much homework these days.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And you've got to use your resources.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Innovative.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Alexa is a good resource.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: It's it just like a modern-day calculator.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: His mom called it cheating, and I think the kid is pretty smart. That's a first grader doing his winter break math. He probably waited a little too late in the game. And he figured out that Alexa had the answer. Maybe it was one of his friends at school. My 8th grader does the same thing with Siri when she's stuck on an algebra problem. I'm like, "You can't do that." And she said, "No, we absolutely can. We can use calculators. Therefore, we can use Siri." It's "No, I want you to figure out how to use a scientific calculator, because that is tough." Anyone can go, "Blah, blah, blah!" But you know - -

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's what it's there for.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: This mother videotaped it and put it on the Internet. That's pretty cool.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I wouldn't know whether to punish him or reward him, though. Because that's pretty creative.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: For a first grader? That's brilliant.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: That's pretty cool.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But you know, this is like an old story made new with technology. Because 15 years ago, it was students using Google to cheat. Wasn't it 15? I can't remember.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And Alexa is just Google for your ears when you think about it. The question you have to ask yourself --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It was actually Ask Jeeves.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Ask Jeeves. Whatever happened to Jeeves? RIP, Jeeves.

utterances.speaker: The question is
utterances.utterance: Is figuring out an answer and finding the answer, is there any difference at this point? Maybe this is the way it's supposed to be. It's supposed to free up your brain for other things. You don't need to figure out answers anymore. All you have to do is find them. We're in -- all the answers are now on our phone. So you don't need math. You don't need algebra, calculus --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Except if you don't have service and you're out in the middle of nowhere.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That will happen when the blue apocalypse happens.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And all you use is your math and all that type of stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And then you don't have service on your phone, and you're screwed. You don't know how to get back home, because you never --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, but I've got a gun and a motorcycle, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: All right. We've got one more. Finally, a huge New Year's Eve show coming up. Kennedy is very serious about it. So she decided to whip her co-hosts into shape with a boot camp. Check it out.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: We are doing mic drills, people. You are going to be interviewing machines. Five, 6, 7, 8. You, them; you, them; you, them. Jenkins, what is your major malfunction?

utterances.speaker: GRIFF JENKINS, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: My arm. My arm's tired.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You know, Kennedy, the things you have to do to get people to just do their jobs.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I hope Jenkins isn't complaining like that on New Year's Eve. He is teeing it up right with Carley Shimkus. And boy, oh, boy, I hope he soaked his elbow or had some Tommy John surgery during the break, because he is going to need to interview the million people who are going to be in Times Square.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Lawrence, you're going to be there, too? You're going to be where?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I'm going to be in New Orleans. Yes, we're going to have fun on Bourbon Street.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And I'm going to be in New York City at Haven Rooftop. We're going to party, and Kennedy's probably going to be yelling at us. But we'll deserve it.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And it will be warmer than last year.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Anything will be. Sam, the butcher's, meat locker will be warmer than Times Square last year.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is that a euphemism?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It is.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Hello. Stay right there. "Fan Mail Friday," it's coming up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Fan Mail Friday," you know the drill. First question comes from John Baker if that's, indeed, his real name. I'm not sure. "What did you say 'no' to that you now sometimes regret?" All right. Marie, I'm going to you first.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I knew you were coming to me first, and I have no answer for this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Come on! You know what?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You should have regretted answering this question.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's my answer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I'll think about it. I've got nothing good, though.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is not a game show. You have to answer the question. Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I said "no" to a date with Quentin Tarantino in 1994. It probably would have been fun.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's like dating a giant chin.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes, but it was right when "Pulp Fiction" came out. So it would have been fun to stick around and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All he would have done was stare at your feet.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's a really good --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Foot fetishist?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Hot!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Lawrence, before I get in trouble.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Now I really regret it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Right when -- what is that crypto-currency?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Bitcoin?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Bitcoin. When it was really buzzing. A person that was an investor told me to get involved with it, and I just didn't. I kind of regret that, because I could have gotten more money.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's true. Although you don't know yet.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jed.

utterances.speaker: BILA
